Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 902d90dacc33c762b44d25595d3be16c47bae444

this seems like a bit of a hack. It seems like we could create a constexpr array instead of re-parsing this string for every command that gets executed. At the very least, this should be done once and saved as a static.

Hi Vernon,

      Could you please review this patch and provide your comments if any.

--Kumar.
Please update the patchset to resolve the build issue so the code review can proceed.
Is there an ETA on when the build changes will be resolved?  The review on this patchset has been blocked for a week.

This patch needs to be abandon, because these implementations are done in the platform specific repo (fb-ipmi-oem). 

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/fb-ipmi-oem/+/53776

I will abandon once the above fb-ipmi-oem patch is merged. I will mark as WIP as of now.

Why a global?  Why not at least a member variable?

Why not change APIs to pass the "host index" around?  Is it always a "host index"?  What happens when the IPMB target isn't a host?

Ack. 

It is not only hosts index, It has other IPMI device number also. We are passing IPMB index as hostIdx in the command request.

What happens when the IPMB target isn't a host ?

Ex : A system has no hosts and 1 debug cards.

     Then, ipmb-channel.json is machine specific, we can configure for debug card entry with IPMB index as 0 only. This is sending to ipmid as hostIdx. So, we  can hostIdx to map the setting manager objects.
     
     Settings manager objects also displays the dbus objects based on machine specific .yml file. we can map these with hostIdx in the same order.

static?  size_t?

Why do we have this?  An arbitrary "ARRAY_SIZE" doesn't give me any information.
Seems like a vector or a hashmap<int, bool> would get rid of a static limit, wouldn't it?

Do we want 'int' or size_t?

You might want to just use a vector?
Done. Updated with vector. The reason I used map earlier is storing and lookup is little easy compared to vector. we need to iterate in vector.

Is there a reason we're using a class member to pass state between functions?  Can we just pass it as a parameter?

If not, can you please document what this is used for and why here?


Suggest `size_t hostIdx = 0` for default initialization at a minimum.

Is there a reason we're using a class member to pass state between functions?  Can we just pass it as a parameter?

All the functions(cacheRestrictedMode, handleRestrictedModeChange, filterMessage) are declared in the same class. So, no need to pass extra parameter to these functions.

> All the functions(cacheRestrictedMode, handleRestrictedModeChange, filterMessage) are declared in the same class. So, no need to pass extra parameter to these functions.

Isn't passing a parameter far more obvious?  I don't know why we'd ever want to use class state for control flow.  This is far less maintainable.
Do we need to add the `hostIdx` to the log anywhere?
Ack.  I think not needed in logs.
In the log, the condition is checking whether restriction mode is true or false. Hence, hostIdx is needed here to check this condition for each host restriction mode.

> Ack.  I think not needed in logs.

Why or why not?  I don't know understand the point of logging a bool that you have no idea what it is associated with.  Is there something earlier in the logging that clearly indicates which host (or IPMB channel) this is associated with?

Done.
Yes. Earlier the implementation was supported only single host. So it indicates restriction modes by default for that single host. Now, we have updated the logic to support for multi hosts and other IPMI devices.

I'm pretty sure this doesn't work.  This assumes that you are iterating exactly in order such that 'begin + hostIdx == end'.  If there is ever a case you run this (or line 133) when that isn't true, the insert will end up shifting values around incorrectly.
You should rarely use anything except `size_t` for an index type.

Probably use `devices[iter]` here to avoid bounds checking.  You already know the bounds are safe.

Alternatively, change the whole for-loop to use range iteration: for (auto& d : devices)

Is there any reason you're not using sdbusplus::asio::getProperty ?  Please use that instead of writing your own method call because I'm pretty sure there are error paths handled in that function you don't handle here.  You'll also be able to use `std::string` directly instead of dealing with variants.
Using async_method_call is the existing implementation. So, I didn't update that logic. I have updated only to get/set the restrictedMode for multi hosts.
Please use range-for syntax.  You have no need for the index here.
I'm confused how this filter is created inside the for loop but used outside of it.  Isn't it overwritten N times?

Earlier implementation used propertiesChanged, so for loop needed to get the all host dbus path.

Now, used propertiesChangedNamespace to filter all the host dbus paths.
It will overwrite N times. I move it to outside of the loop.

Suggest calculating this when needed rather than maintaining it.

index = std::distance(std::begin(devices), &dev)

This can be inserted into the lambda parameter.

Now that the filter is rewritten it is much easier to see what is going on here...  The original for-loop you had is fine (with devices.size() based iteration).  There is probably a std::transform you could do instead, but it likely isn't as readable as this.
I don't think this code can actually throw.  Is there something that happened in the refactor that got rid of a function call that caused out_of_range?  I think it was from the `devices.at` before.

I think you misunderstood me.  Now you're passing a reference to an iterator into a lambda which is called async.  You'll never get the right value here.

Switch the for-loop to:

  for (auto& dev : devices)

Switch the lambda to:

  [this, index = std::distance(devices.begin(), &dev)](...)

Again, you don't need 'at'; use operator[].

at provides bounds checking and throws an exception.  operator[] does not.  You already know you are within bounds because the loop iteration is set up that way purposefully.

Prefer emplace over insert for efficiency.

  deviceList.emplace(devices[index], index);

Try again.  I've given you the exact code two other times now.

Hint: devices.end() is certainly _not_ what you are looking for.

std::distance is expecting iterators as a input parameter.
distance( InputIt first, InputIt last )

Here, getting compilation issue when we use 'std::distance(devices.begin(), &dev)'.

&dev - type is const string.  

Below is the error log for the reference. 

"error: no matching function for call to 'distance(std::vector<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char> >::const_iterator, const std::__cxx11::basic_string<char>*)'
|    87 |     [this, index = std::distance(devices.begin(), &dev)](boost::system::error_code ec, ipmi::Value v) "


Note : When we use std::distance(devices.begin(), devices.end()), works fine and validated.
I know for certain std::end is not what you want. all this is doing is giving you the size of the vector.

std::distance(devices.begin(), devices.end()-1) also works and will get the correct index. 

Could you please provide your thoughts on this ?

> std::distance(devices.begin(), devices.end()-1) also works and will get the correct index. 

Can you explain to me how two static ends of the container can possibly give you a valid index as you are iterating through it?  You're attempting to obtain a dynamic value (the index) from static ones (the begin/end).  There is no way this works.

https://godbolt.org/z/j4hPad1Tv

Either of these approaches would be fine in this case.  They are both within 1 asm instruction of each other in length.

I have confirmed that this works in this code:
    index = std::distance(&*std::begin(devices), &dev)
better to use log<level::ERR> instead of std:cerr.
Looks like my earlier vote was lost but there was only minor changes.
What is key for this map? Pls add doxygen style comments for functions.

Done. Added comments for all the functions.

This map std::map<std::string, size_t>& deviceList has key as dbus path of supported devices and value as it's index.
Is there a service dependency with the settings manager that ensures the restriction modes are populated already?
yes. Added settings daemon service(xyz.openbmc_project.Settings.service) as dependency service. will submit a separate patch for this in meta-phosphor.
nit: move it after the for loop where it is used
Probably should be static constexpr too.
